name: (3,4-dimethoxyphenyl)(4-methoxyphenyl)methanone
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-2112

name: (3,4-dimethoxyphenyl)(4-methoxyphenyl)methanone
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-2112
Reason: The compound in question is a ketone with two aromatic rings, each of which is substituted with methoxy groups. The basic unit for comparison is benzophenone, which has a melting point of 48 degrees Celsius. The addition of methoxy groups to the phenyl rings will affect the melting point. Methoxy groups tend to increase the melting point due to the increased polarity and the ability to participate in dipole-dipole interactions, which stabilizes the crystalline structure. Each methoxy group contributes to this effect. However, the increase each group offers may not be additive due to steric hindrance and the electronic effects of multiple substituents on the same ring. The weight and volume of these substituents also slightly reduces the packing efficiency in the crystal lattice which can counter some of the increase in the melting point. Given these factors, the prediction can be estimated as follows: Starting with benzophenone at 48°C, each methoxy group might add approximately 10°C to the melting point due to increased polarity and potential for dipole-dipole interactions. There are three methoxy groups, so the estimated total effect could be around 30°C. Therefore, the predicted melting point would be 48 + 30 = 78°C, close to the actual value.
